San Francisco Giants.passage: San Francisco Giants (also called the Giants) are a professional baseball team based in San Francisco, California. They are a member of both Major League Baseball (MLB) and the National League (NL) West division. The Giants have won two World Series championships, in 2010 and 2012, and three National League pennants, in 2012, 2014, and 2018. The team plays its home games at Oracle Park, located on the San Francisco waterfront in the SoMa neighborhood near downtown. The franchise was established in 1883 as the New York Gothams and played in New York's Polo Grounds II, which no longer exists. The team was renamed to the New York Giants in 1885. The Giants relocated to San Francisco in 1958 and became known as the San Francisco Giants, playing their first game as the Giants in 1959. In 2010, the Giants won their first World Series title in 56 years. They won their second World Series in 2012, and their third in 2014. The Giants have the longest World Series championship drought among all current MLB teams. As of the end of the 2018 season, the Giants have the third-most wins in MLB history. Sporting CP.passage: Sporting CP (Portuguese: Sporting Clube de Portugal, IPA: [ˈspɔːtɐŋ kluˈβeɾ pɨ ˈdɨ ˈtɨɾɐ ʃuˈpʃip]; "Sporting Club of Portugal"), commonly known as Sporting, Sporting CP or Sporting Clube de Portugal, is a Portuguese professional football club based in Lisbon. England.passage: England (;[ɪŋʈɪˈlɑːndʒə];[ˈlʌndʒə])[a], also known as the United Kingdom, the UK, or Britain, is a country that is part of the European Union. It is separated from continental Europe by the North Sea to its east and the English Channel to its south. It covers five-eighths of the island of Great Britain (which lies off the north-west of the European mainland) including the island of Ireland, and includes over one million km2 (390,000 sq mi) of maritime territory, the devolved nations of Scotland and Wales, and over 300 smaller islands. England has four major urban areas: Greater London, the Midlands, the North East, and the South East, and includes over 200 major cities and towns. The capital is London, which is the largest metropolitan area in the world. England's territory has its own history, culture, and language, which are strongly associated with Britain, the island's largest island. The history of England begins with the Stone Age, and it was one of the centres of the ancient world, being home to the Romans and later the Anglo-Saxons. In the Middle Ages, England was the largest, wealthiest and most powerful country in Europe, playing a pivotal role in the development of parliamentary democracy and the Enlightenment.

Emirates Stadium.passage: Emirates Stadium (officially known as Etihad Stadium) is a football stadium in the London Borough of Islington, in the city of London. It is the home of Arsenal and formerly held home matches of West Ham United and the England national team. Bavaria.passage: Bavaria (German: [ˈbɔʏɐʁaɪ̯a] ( listen); Franconian: Bawer [ˈbɔʏɐ̯ʁa] ( listen); Italian: Baviera [ˈbɔːʒiːˈreːɡa] ( listen); Latin: Bavaria [ˈbeːwaɪ̯ra] ( listen)) is a German-speaking federal state in southern Germany. With an area of over 70,500 km2 (27,200 sq mi) it is the largest state by area and the second-largest state by population (after Brandenburg). Montjuïc.passage: Montjuïc (Catalan: "Muntjuc", Spanish: "Montjuïc"; locally: "Monjuic" or "Monsjuïc") is a large hill located in the city of Barcelona. The hill is named after the Benedictine order of monks who owned a monastery on its slopes from the 10th century until the early 19th century, when it was suppressed by the Spanish government during the Spanish Inquisition. The monastery was demolished in 1811, but its church still stands and is known as the Basilica of Montjuïc (Catalan: "Basílica del Montjuïc"; Spanish: "Basílica de Montjuïc"). The hill is home to many of the most popular attractions in Barcelona. It is a major recreation area in the city, and is also a major transport hub, with the largest public transport station in the city, the Barcelona Sants railway station, located on the hill. It is also home to many important sports facilities, including the National Stadium, home to the FC Barcelona football team, and the Montjuïc horse races. The hill is also home to the Montjuïc castle, the oldest castle in continuous use in Europe, and the Parc del Centre del Poblenou and Parc de Joan Miró, two major parks.

qae_pairs.question: What year was the Basilica of Montjuïc built?
qae_pairs.explanation: The Basilica of Montjuïc was built in 1811.

qae_pairs.answer: the Parc del Centre del Poblenou

Spain.passage: Spain (Spanish: España, pronounced [esˈpaɣa]), officially the Kingdom of Spain, is a country in Europe, mainly located on the Iberian Peninsula. It is bordered to the south and east by the Mediterranean Sea; to the north and northwest by France and Andorra; to the northeast by Portugal; and to the southwest by Gibraltar and the Strait of Gibraltar. The Iberian Peninsula lies on the western end of Eurasia, and the country's location on the southern shore of the Mediterranean allows for maritime trade and navigation between Europe and the Americas and Africa. Spain is the largest country in the European Union by area and the second-largest in the world by land area. It is the sixth-largest country in the world by population, with over 47 million people. The capital is Madrid, the largest city is Barcelona, and the main islands in the archipelago are the Balearic Islands.

west London.passage: The western part of the London Borough of Wandsworth is sometimes known as Wandsworth Common or Wandsworth (the name of the common is derived from the Saxon word wan-dæg, meaning "wandering day"). It is served by three stations on the London Overground network, Wandsworth Common, Wandsworth Road and Tooting Broadway.

Bayern Munich.passage: Bayern Munich is a German sports club based in Bavaria. The club is the most successful in German football with 37 championships, including 26 national championships and 11 consecutive championships from 2012 to 2019, a record in the history of the German championship. The club is one of the Big Three in German football, alongside 1. FC Nürnberg and Borussia Dortmund, the latter of which is its traditional rival. Bayern has won the most German championships of all time and holds the record for most titles in the DFB-Pokal, the UEFA Champions League and the FIFA Club World Cup. The club has a large fan base and is one of the wealthiest sports clubs in the world.

The Yellow Army.passage:
The Yellow Army is a term used to refer to the Chinese Nationalist Army (KMT), the main military of the Republic of China (ROC) between 1928 and 1949. It was also referred to as the Chinese Nationalist Revolutionary Army (CNRRA) and the Nationalist Chinese Army, and was commanded by the Nationalist Government of the Republic of China. The term Yellow Armies is sometimes used to refer to the National Revolutionary Army of the Republic of China (1938–1949), the Kuomintang (Chinese Nationalist Party) army, the People's Liberation Army (PLA) or the People's Liberation Army of the Republic of China. Turin.passage:
Turin (Piedmont)
Turin ( ; ; ; ) is a city in Piedmont, Italy, the capital of the Piedmont region. The population of the city proper (comune) was 886,972 in 2016 within a metropolitan area of 1,262,500 inhabitants (about 2.7 million people in total, including the surrounding urban agglomeration), making it the third-most populous city in Italy after Milan and Rome, and the fourth-most populous in the European Union. The historical city centre, located within a bend of the Po River, is an example of Renaissance-era urban planning, and its architectural heritage has been listed as a World Heritage Site by UNESCO. The Porta Palatina and the Mole Antonelliana are landmarks of the city. Turin was one of the host cities of the 2006 Winter Olympics. The city is home to several major companies, including Fiat-Chrysler Automobiles, Ferrari, Juventus Football Club, and STMicroelectronics, the largest microchip foundry in the world. Turin is one of the wealthiest and most advanced cities in Italy and is ranked as a Gamma-Plus world city. The University of Turin and the Turin Polytechnic are among Italy's oldest and most prestigious educational institutions.

qae_pairs.explanation: Turin is located in the Po River valley.

qae_pairs.explanation: Turin is in Italy.

Old Trafford.passage: The original Old Trafford was a football stadium in Old Trafford, Greater Manchester, England, which was the primary home ground of Manchester United from 1910 until moving to Old Trafford Cricket Ground in 1910. The stadium was demolished in 1910, and a new one was built on the same site, opening in 1910. It was the largest stadium in England by capacity until 1958, when the 54,074 all-seater Maine Road stadium opened in the neighbouring town of Manchester. The stadium held 66,338 people at the start of the 1958–59 season, but this was reduced to 60,097 by safety legislation, and then to 53,000 by the Taylor Report in 1990.

Real Madrid Club de Fútbol.passage: Real Madrid Club de Fútbol (Spanish pronunciation: [ˈɾaɪɾa matˈðɾaɣo ˈkluβ ðɾa matˈðaɣo], Royal Madrid Football Club) is a professional football club based in Madrid, Spain, that plays in La Liga. The club was founded on 6 March 1902 as Madrid Football Club, and was later renamed as Madrid Football Club de Fútbol. The club's name was changed for the second time on 13 March 1913 to what it is currently known as: "Real Madrid Club de Fútbol". The club's crest depicts the royal crown of Spain, which signifies the royal patronage granted to the institution by King Alfonso XIII in 1920. Real Madrid is one of the most successful clubs in Spanish football, winning a record 34 La Liga titles, 17 Copas del Rey, a record 9 Supercopa de España titles, 2 UEFA Cups and 2 UEFA Champions League titles. Real Madrid was ranked by Forbes as the world's most valuable sports team, with a brand value of $3.

the National League.passage: The National League of Professional Baseball Clubs (NL) is one of two leagues that make up the highest level of professional baseball in North America, the other being Major League Baseball (MLB). It is a "third major league" in the United States and Canada, the other two being MLB and the minor league organization known as the farm system of the MLB. It was originally formed by the American Association (AA) to compete with the National Association (NA) as the major leagues of the 19th century. The National League was formed in 1876 as a competing major league, and the American League formed in 1901 as a competing major league, with both leagues claiming to hold first place in the "major league" hierarchy, and both claiming to be the "real" major league and not the other. The NL and the AA both agreed to a plan in which the AA clubs would join the NL as its 12th and 13th teams, in exchange for agreeing for the NL to be considered the top league and to be considered as such in the records kept for "major league" baseball. The AA clubs would retain their own records and be able to leave the NL at any time without penalty. The NL clubs would retain their existing records. The NL was formed in 1876 as a competing major league to the NA.

qae_pairs.explanation: The National League was formed in 1876 as a competing major league to the National Association.
